TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Coarse-loamy, mixed, superactive Typic Cryaquolls

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Rosane fine sandy loam - grassland.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
01--1 inch to 0; undecomposed and partially decomposed organic material, mostly from rushes, sedges, and water-tolerant grasses.  (0 to 3 inches thick).
A11g--0 to 8 inches; grayish brown (10YR 5/2) fine sandy loam, very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) moist; common, fine, distinct, strong-brown (7.5YR 5/6) moist mottles; moderate, granular structure; soft, very friable; neutral; gradual, wavy boundary.  (6 to 10 inches thick)
A12g--8 to 16 inches; gray (2.5Y 5/1) fine sandy loam, very dark gray (2.5Y 3/1) moist; many, large, prominent, strong-brown (7.5YR 5/6) moist mottles; weak, medium, subangular blocky structure parting to moderate, fine, granular structure; soft, very friable; neutral; gradual wavy boundary.  (4 to 9 inches thick)
B2g--16 to 28 inches; gray (5Y 6/1) fine sandy loam, dark gray (5Y 4/1) moist; many, large, prominent, strong-brown (7.5YR 5/6) moist mottles; massive; soft, very friable; 5 percent pebbles; neutral; clear wavy boundary.  (0 to 21 inches thick)
2Cg--28 to 60 inches; sand and gravel; many large prominent bright colored mottles.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Lake County, Colorado; 250 feet east and 200 feet south of the northwest corner of Sec. 3, T. 8 E., R. 49 S.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Thickness of the mollic epipedon ranges from 7 to 20 inches, thickness of the solum ranges from 15 to 40 inches, and depth to the contrasting sand and gravel substratum ranges from 23 to 40 inches.  Typically these soils are noncalcareous to depths of more than 60 inches and are noncalcareous in excess of 40 inches in all pedons.  The soil is 80 to 100 percent base saturated.  These soils have fluctuating water tables that rise to near the surface of the ground many times during most years.  Rock fragments in the upper part of the control section range from 0 to 15 percent by volume, and from 35 to 70 percent in the lower part.  The solum is neutral or mildly alkaline.
The A1 horizon has hue of 5Y through 10YR, value of 4 or 5, 2 or 3 moist, and chroma of 1 through 3.  It is typically strongly mottled in the lower part.  This horizon usually has granular or crumb structure, but it has weak subangular blocky structure in some pedons.  It is soft or slightly hard.
The B2g horizon has hue of 5Y or 2.5Y, value of 5 or 6, 4 or 5 moist, and chroma of 0 through 2.  Usually it has subangular blocky structure and parts to granular or crumb, but is massive in some pedons.  This horizon is typically fine sandy loam with clay ranging from 8 to 18 percent.
The 2Cg horizon typically is not calcareous but is weakly calcareous below 40 inches in some pedons.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  This is the Fourlog (T) series.  Fourlog soils lack sand and gravel within the particle-size control section.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  The Rosane soils are on depressional or concave portions of floodplains, terraces, or low alluvial fans.  Slope gradients range from 0 to 6 percent.  These soils formed in relatively uniform mixed alluvial materials.  At the type location the average annual precipitation is approximately 12 inches, with a peak during the months of April through September.  The mean annual temperature is 36 degrees F., and the mean summer temperature is 51 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Chaffee, Newfork, and Pierian soils.  Chaffee soils have a mollic epipedon 24 to 50 inches thick and have a sandy loam control section.  Pierian soils are excessively drained and lack mottles.  Newfork soils are sandy-skeletal.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Poorly drained; slow runoff; moderately rapid to rapid permeability but soil has a high water table.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  These soils are used principally as native pastureland.  Native hay crops may be harvested in some years.  Native vegetation is mainly water-tolerant grasses, sedges, rushes, and willows.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  High mountain valleys of central Colorado.  The series is of small extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Last updated by the state 4/80.
The superactive cation exchange activity class was added in 03/2003 to the taxonomic classification by the National Soil Survey Center on request of the Lakewood MLRA office, without review of the soil series property data. The remainder of this document has not been updated.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
